column1: The COVID-19 pandemic in Belgium forms part of the ongoing worldwide pandemic of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). The virus was confirmed to have spread to Belgium on 4 February 2020
column2: when a Belgian national out of a group of nine Belgians repatriated from Wuhan to Brussels was reported to have tested positive for the coronavirus. Transmission within Belgium was then confirmed in early March; authorities linked this to holidaymakers returning from Northern Italy at the end of the half-term holidays. The epidemic increased rapidly in March–April 2020. By the end of March all 10 provinces of the country had registered cases.As of 25 June
column3: the Belgian authorities had reported 61
column4: 007 confirmed cases
column5: with a total of 9
column6: 726 deaths and at least 17
column7: 688 discharged patients. The actual number of infections
column9: is likely to be much higher than the number of diagnosed cases
column10: as laboratory tests are limited to specific people and/or people with severe symptoms
column11: and because many people with mild or no symptoms do not seek medical help
column12: even as they are likely to be transmitting the virus.Belgium was among the world's worst-affected countries in terms of the number of deaths per head of population (excluding microstates). For example
column14: it was reported that there had been 819 deaths per one million head of population
column19: Belgium may have been over-reporting the actual number of cases. Unlike many other countries
column20: which publish figures based primarily on confirmed hospital deaths
column21: the death figures reported by the Belgian authorities include deaths in the community
column23: confirmed to have been caused by the coronavirus
column24: as well as a much larger number of such deaths suspected to have been caused by the virus
column25: even if the person was not tested. Such differences in methods of counting complicate any attempt to compare death rates in different countries.

column2: the World Health Organization (WHO) confirmed that a novel coronavirus was the cause of a respiratory illness in a cluster of people in Wuhan City
column3: Hubei Province
column4: China
column5: which was reported to the WHO on 31 December 2019. First reports of the coronavirus disease started to appear in the Belgian media around 8 January.The case fatality ratio for COVID-19 has been much lower than SARS of 2003
column6: but the transmission has been significantly greater
column7: with a significant total death toll.

column2: Belgian nationals living in Hubei were repatriated on an evacuation flight landing at Melsbroek Air Base close to Brussels
column3: before being transferred to the Military Hospital of Neder-over-Heembeek where they underwent a 14-day quarantine and got tested for infection with the virus.On 4 February
column4: it was announced one of the repatriated has tested positive for the novel coronavirus
column5: the first case in Belgium. The patient
column6: an asymptomatic 54-year-old male
column7: was then transferred to the Saint Peter's Hospital in Brussels
column8: one of the two referral centres in the country.On 21 February
column9: a group of ten Belgian citizens were allowed to return to Belgium after having been constrained on the MS Westerdam cruise ship for several days.On 24 February
column10: following the spread of the COVID-19 in northern Italy
column11: a hundred Belgian citizens were put in quarantine in the H10 Costa Adeje Palace in Tenerife that was put on lockdown. Fifteen of them were allowed to travel back to Belgium on 28 February and the remainder on 5 March
column12: without having been tested for the coronavirus upon arrival.

column2: a second case was confirmed in Belgium
column3: a Dutch-speaking woman who had returned from Crépy-en-Valois in one of the regions affected in France.The yearly one week school holiday around carnival lasted from 22 February until 1 March 2020. Many people go on ski vacation during that period and the number of detected virus infections rose sharply upon the return of people from holidays in affected areas.

column2: six additional cases
column3: making a total of eight
column4: had been diagnosed. Five were found in Flanders and one in Brussels
column5: all six infected people having come back from Northern Italy.As of 3 March
column6: six further cases were confirmed
column7: making a total of 14 cases. Amongst the new cases
column8: a 17-year from Tienen and one person from Sint-Niklaas returned from a ski vacation in northern Italy
column10: two cases from Couthuin and a 65-year-old male from Eupen who presented relatively severe symptoms and had not been to any of the regions with a higher risk of infection. Steven Van Gucht of the Scientific Committee predicted that in the worst-case scenario the epidemic would cause 13
column14: 000 hospitalisations and 500 to 700 patients in intensive care. In a later interview van Gucht refined his opinion
column15: adding that 70% of the population (approximately 8 million persons) could become infected.By 4 March 10 new cases were confirmed
column16: making a total of 23. Nine of the new infected individuals had recently returned from Italy. The other patient had had contact with a prior case. Four cases were in the Leuven area
column18: and one in Pelt. In Wevelgem
column19: a family and a primary school teacher were diagnosed with the coronavirus upon their return from the North of Italy. The Flemish Agency for Care and Health advised the school not to close down. A retirement home in Gooik stopped receiving visitors after discovering that one of its employees could have been in contact with the coronavirus
column20: a precaution the Flemish Agency for Care and Health qualified as inappropriate and "excessive".On 4 March
column21: the European Defence Agency (EDA) confirmed that a staff member had tested positive for coronavirus
column22: marking the first confirmed case in the agencies of the European Union. He had returned from Italy the previous week and attended a meeting with about thirty other European Union officials before he had started to feel ill. A military staff member of the European External Action Service who attended the meeting then also began to experience symptoms. The EDA cancelled all meetings until 13 March
column23: and other EU institutions also took precautions.On 5 March 27 new confirmed cases were reported by the government (16 in Flanders
column24: nine in Wallonia and two in Brussels)
column25: bringing the total to 50. Of the 50 people then infected one had recovered
column26: 48 were quarantined in their homes and one person was being treated in the Sint-Pietersziekenhuis. The new cases were reported to be in Knokke-Heist
column28: Doomkerke (Ruiselede) and Vlierzele (part of Sint-Lievens-Houtem).On 6 March 59 new cases were reported by the government
column29: bringing the total to 109 (65 in Flanders
column31: 31 in Wallonia and one recovered). The new cases were amongst others reported in Oosterzele and Sint-Katelijne-Waver. The FPS Health then confirmed for the first time that infections had occurred in Belgium.

column1: On 7 March 60 new cases were confirmed by the government (40 in Flanders
column2: five in Brussels and 15 in Wallonia)
column3: bringing the total to 169 (105 in Flanders
column4: 17 in Brussels
column5: 46 in Wallonia and one recovered). The new cases were amongst others reported in Houthalen
column6: Melle
column7: Lokeren
column10: Tildonk and Poppel. The FPS Health mentioned generally that "more and more infections are being contracted locally" but did not provide information on how many.From 422 samples analysed on 7 March 31 were reported positive on 8 March (16 in Flanders
column11: eight in Brussels and seven in Wallonia)
column12: bringing the number of infections to 200. The FPS Health then reported local circulation of the virus in different parts of the country.On 10 March
column13: the total number of confirmed cases was 267.On 11 March
column14: the first death on Belgian territory due to COVID-19 was reported
column15: of a 90-year-old female patient from Brussels who was being treated in Etterbeek. Two more patients died on the same day
column17: and one of 86 who died in Sint-Genesius-Rode.On 12 March
column18: two new infections were detected as well as 32 suspected cases in retirement home Ter Kameren in Watermaal-Bosvoorde
column19: one of the biggest retirement homes of the Brussels region. The total number of confirmed cases rose to 399. Approximately 20 patients out of those 399 were being treated in intensive care. The president of the European Commission
column20: Ursula von der Leyen informed the entire staff that seven of their colleagues had tested positive
column21: six of them in Belgium. She also instructed "all colleagues in non-critical functions" to work from home with immediate effect until 5 April
column22: while those "who ensure critical functions" would need to work in two shifts to minimize the risk of contagion.By 14 March 689 cases were confirmed with four deaths.On 21 March it was observed that more than half of the patients in the hospital Oost-Limburg in Genk were of Turkish origin. Secretary of State Zuhal Demir urged the Turkish community in Limburg to abide by the quarantine measures.On 26 March
column23: Sciensano published a map that showed that the highest recorded concentrations of infections were found in Alken and Sint-Truiden (Limburg) and Quévy and Honnelles (Hainaut). The hotspot in Alken is thought to have been caused because of two parties that were allowed to gather over the weekend of 7 March. The mayor of Sint-Truiden
column24: who was herself infected by the new coronavirus
column25: mentioned she did not understand the reason for the high incidence in her town. The high level of cases in the affluent municipality of Bonheiden is thought to be linked with the number of travellers who had returned from ski resorts in the North of Italy around the beginning of March. While the high incidence in Honnelles could be linked to an outbreak in a centre for disabled people
column26: the mayor of Quévy had no idea what caused the large outbreak in her municipality but complained of the lack of communication and protective equipment.On the daily press conference of 27 March Van Gucht announced that a cat had been infected by its owner. This was only the third time the infection of a companion animal by its human companion had been reported worldwide. The cat had developed respiratory and digestive problems.The additional number of people reported as having tested positive for the novel coronavirus peaked on 28 March compared to the previous days. The peak occurred because more persons were being tested and because a major Walloon laboratory that had not reported any cases up to that point then belatedly reported 500 additional cases from a past period.As of 29 March
column28: 000 Belgian citizens were stuck abroad due to travel restrictions worldwide
column32: it was announced that because of the high burden on some hospitals in the provinces of Limburg and Hainaut
column33: a dispersal plan for ICU patients had been activated.Jan Eyckmans of the Federal Public Service Health claimed hospitals increased their number of ICUs from 1900 to 2650 over a period of two weeks time
column34: corresponding to an increase from 16.5 to 23.0 ICUs per 100
column36: on the daily press conference of the Belgian National Crisis Centre of 28 March Dr Emmanuel André of the UZ Leuven mentioned that the number of 789 ICUs corresponded to 43% of the capacity
column37: bringing the total capacity to 1835 instead of 2650
column38: while Dr Van Gucht quoted the capacity as 2081 units. The newspaper De Standaard mentioned the number of 1765 on 31 March and 2393 on 3 April.

column2: it became clear that the peak of the only wave thus far of the pandemic within the country was expected in early April. On 8 April
column3: a drop in the number of active hospitalisations could be seen
column4: which meant that a peak in them
column5: and thus perhaps in infections
column6: had been reached a couple days earlier. The mortality peak would follow a bit later
column7: and was retrospectively observed to have occurred on 12 April. The peak was 417 deaths in 24 hours.

column1: On 1 June Belgium's Prince Joachim issued a public apology following news that he tested positive for COVID-19 after he attended a party in Spain
column2: in violation of the country's lockdown.
Belgium began gradually to ease the lockdown measures
column3: which were the measures taken from March 18 to combat the spread of the coronavirus. For example
column4: as of 11 May
column5: all shops are allowed to be open for the public but under certain conditions (e.g. visits are limited to 30 minutes).

column1: Cafes and restaurants were allowed to be open as of 8 June.

column3: 000 people demonstrated in Brussels
column4: in the Black Lives Matter demonstration
column5: with corona measures still in place. It was strongly disapproved by Minister President of Flanders Jan Jambon who called it detrimental to the spread of the virus.

column2: three Chiro Flanders youth camps were canceled in West Flanders and Antwerp because 11 leaders were found to be infected.

column1: On 25 July new regulations made it compulsory to wear face coverings in most indoor spaces and busy outdoor spaces. Visitors to a pub have to wear face coverings at least until they have found a seat. Those breaking the rules could be fined up to 250 Euros.

column2: the government published new social distancing rules to come into effect in Belgium from 29 July
column3: whereby the number of closer contacts of separate households was restricted to a group of maximum 5 people (the so-called "bubble of five"). With people who are not part of your bubble
column4: safety distance had to be respected. People could only go to a restaurant within their family and within the bubble.

column2: in response to a flare-up in Antwerp
column3: measures are being tightened locally. E.g. a curfew is being imposed for the entire province. Individuals are required to stay in their homes from 11.30 pm to 6 am. It lasted 1 month.

column1: As of end July and during August and September the number of new corona infections per day began to rise again in Belgium.

column2: an average of 1
column3: 100 new infections per day were counted.  Belgium had then passed the milestone of 100
column4: 000 confirmed coronavirus infections. The number of testing was now much increased. In September an average of more than 30
column5: 000 tests were carried out daily compared to ca. 5
column6: 000 tests daily begin April. The increased number of tests could partially but not fully explain the increasing number of infections. The percentage of positive COVID-19 cases of all samples taken has risen in September to more than 3%. It was more than 5% at the peak in April and less than 1% at the end of June.

column2: the number of hospitalised coronavirus patients had continued to remain at a low level. On 18 September
column3: a total of 260 patients were receiving hospital care due to COVID-19
column4: compared to almost 7
column5: 000 at the peak of the epidemic. Belgian virologist Marc Van Ranst advocates against easing and in favour of stricter measures
column6: calling the situation in Belgium on September 15 a recipe for disaster. Other experts reacted in the media and questioned whether the situation had to be seen as alarming.On September 17
column7: at least 77 youngsters from West Flanders tested positive for COVID-19 after a holiday in the Portuguese resort of Albufeira.On 24 September
column8: new coronavirus restrictions have been announced by the government. The restrictions were eased on some points. The rule of the bubble of 5 was changed: each person in a household could have closer contact with up to 5 persons
column9: with different persons each month.Beginning of October the average number of daily new infections had risen to 1440. The situation in Belgium was no exception compared to other countries in the EU.

column1: === Covid infections at the Doel Nuclear Power Station ===

Medio October 2020 26 members of the working people at the power plant were tested positive on covid.  At that time the possibility of further infections could not be ruled out. Working at home - if possible - was stimulated to control the breakout. Among the employees who dropped out
column2: there were also members of staff who fulfill important tasks in the nuclear power plant. But Engie Electrabel assured that the safety of the nuclear power plant would not be compromised for the time being. During the first wave in the spring
column3: far fewer infections were detected.

Belgium issued a travel notice advising against non-essential flights to China
column3: Hong Kong excluded
column4: with some travel companies cancelling all flights to China.On 1 March
column5: as a second case of coronavirus was confirmed in Belgium
column6: phase 2 of the health risk containment strategy was activated. The mayor of Sint-Lambrechts-Woluwe
column7: Olivier Maingain
column8: was one of the only mayors to take measures to prevent the spreading of the new coronavirus by restricting access to schools
column9: sports facilities and public places for persons returning from areas at risk and only a few schools
column10: such as the International School Ghent
column11: quarantined pupils returning from infected areas
column13: the government advised citizens to cancel any indoor scheduled events to be attended by more than 1
column14: 000 people for the month of March. Prime Minister Wilmès stressed this was not an interdiction but rather a recommendation. Schools remained open but are advised to cancel both trips abroad and multi-day excursions in general. Companies were advised to have their personnel work from home as much as possible and allow flexible working times to allow a better spread of public transport use throughout the day. The authorities called this reinforced phase 2.Late in the evening on 12 March
column15: after a meeting of the National Security Council
column16: the Belgian government moved into the federal phase of crisis management
column17: and ordered the closure of schools
column20: and the cancellation of all public gatherings for sporting
column21: cultural or festive purposes from Friday 13 March at midnight onwards. It was stressed that the measures taken were not a lockdown because people were not required to stay home.

column2: the National Security Council decided to take additional measures
column3: based on the spread of COVID-19 in Belgium and on recommendations of experts. Stricter social distancing measures were imposed from noon the following day until 5 April
column4: with non-essential travel prohibited
column5: non-essential shops to close
column6: gatherings banned
column7: with penalties for corporate and individual persons who failed to comply with the restrictions.On 20 March at 3 pm Belgium closed its borders to all non-essential travel. Earlier
column8: the governor of West Flanders had complained about Dutch and French citizens coming to Belgium for tourism or shopping
column9: while mayors of municipalities close to the border with the Netherlands such as Paul Van Miert of Turnhout urged their Dutch counterparts to request their national authorities in the Netherlands to implement similar measures as in Belgium
column10: to stop Belgian citizens going to Dutch cafés or restaurants. From 25 March onwards

column12: the National Security Council and the governments decided to extend the measures until 19 April (end of the Easter vacation). On 15 April
column13: the containment measures were extended until the 3 May.

column2: the Belgian authorities
column3: mostly through their federal Minister of health Maggie De Block
column4: had focused on reassuring by asserting that there was no reason to panic

column7: at the end of January

column1: While the COVID-19 was already spreading to all regions of Italy in late February

column7: an umbrella organisation in the field of health care and care for the elderly

column12: 000 people for indoor events. The BVAS/ABSyM
column13: the biggest medical trade union in Belgium

column17: including two members of the Scientific Committee for Coronavirus
column18: urged the authorities to take decisive measures and to avoid non-binding instructions and guidelines. Similarly
column21: judged the actions of the federal authorities insufficient and therefore ordered the ban on all indoor and outdoor activities in his municipality.Some media made positive criticism
column22: such as the Financial Times who praised Belgium for its handling of the coronavirus crisis
column23: claiming Belgium had shown that "a fragmented country" could still produce a clear response to the pandemic – by taking decisive actions earlier than other countries – and pointing out the daily briefings are not held by politicians but by scientific experts and spokespersons. De Standaard praised Steven Van Gucht

column1: Just as many countries in the world
column2: Belgium faced a shortage of personal protective equipment (PPE) such as respirators
column3: surgical masks or face shields.

column2: Belgian newspapers highlighted the shortage of respirators and surgical masks and a retailer questioned whether Belgian would have enough masks if there were to be an outbreak of the virus
column3: but the Federal Public Service Health claimed the Belgian hospitals had sufficient stock. On 8 March
column4: Maggie De Block stated she had a solution for the shortage of masks but was unwilling to disclose the potential vendor and the number of masks involved. On 15 March De Standaard newspaper reported that the masks had not been delivered on time
column5: and the following day De Block announced that her department's order of 5 million masks might have involved fraud. On 16 March
column6: De Standaard reported that De Block had blundered by ordering all 5 million masks from a single company (M.O.S.S.A. vof)
column7: a consultancy firm that had no track record in the medical field and was owned by Mahmut Öz
column8: a Belgo-Turkish politician from her own political affiliation. On 20 March
column9: a shipment from China of 5 million masks arrived at the airport of Bierset
column10: but these were surgical masks and not the type of respirators required to protect the medical staff. Hospitals such as the Centre Hospitalier Interrégional Edith Cavell (CHIREC) reported that they were in dire need of protective masks. On 25 March
column11: PVDA-member of parliament Sofie Merckx complained that since 2009 the various governments had not renewed the strategic reserves of mouth masks due to cost cutting measures in the health care system. Upon reaching their expiration date in 2018
column12: minister of health Maggie De Block decided to destroy and not replace 6 million face masks.

column2: Marc Van Ranst confirmed Belgium was facing a shortage of reagents to do widespread COVID-19 testing
column3: and the laboratory reference (National Reference Centre) at the UZ Leuven was therefore forced to apply a triage system and to limit the number of tests. Two surgeons from the Brussels Saint Pierre hospital addressed an open letter to prime minister Wilmès on 22 March demanding increased testing.

column2: the organisation of care homes falls under the regional authorities. On 11 March the care homes were closed for all visitors in Wallonia and Brussels
column3: and a day later in Flanders.After the closure
column4: the sector requested more protective equipment
column5: more training and guidelines for caretakers on how to handle infected patients
column6: and more tests. However

column10: several care homes started to execute tests on their own. Meanwhile
column11: several homes got hit hard with dozens of deaths

column13: and being very late with an emergency plan. Only on 21 April
column14: masks were advised for all personnel in contact with patients.On 10 April
column15: about 40% of all COVID-19 deaths in Belgium occurred in care homes. In Brussels
column16: coronavirus cases have been confirmed in 116 of the 146 care homes.

column2: Belgium had very high mortality figures
column3: the highest death rate from COVID-19 in the world at that time.Steven Van Gucht from Sciensano explained this was partly due to a difference in counting
column4: compared to other countries. In Belgium
column5: around 46% of the COVID-19 deaths occurred in hospital and 53% occurred in care homes; and while the deaths in hospital are all confirmed by a test
column6: only 5% of the deaths in care homes are confirmed by a test
column7: the other 95% being suspected cases. The Netherlands on the other hand
column8: only counted confirmed cases.This way of counting was criticised by Flemish Minister for Tourism
column10: as it would portray Belgium as bad in the fight against coronavirus and also would harm the Belgian reputation of being a prominent country in the pharmaceutical and biotech industries. Some doctors complained that deaths caused by other pathologies and causes have been lumped into the COVID-19 category. The virologist Marc Van Ranst
column11: member of the Belgian Scientific Committee for Coronavirus
column12: also criticised the way of counting
column13: saying it is "dumb" that almost all deaths occurring in care homes are being counted as COVID-19 deaths
column14: leading to an overestimation according to him.Belgian authorities however defend their strategy for being the most transparent and the most detailed method
column15: even if it results in numbers that are "sometimes overestimated". According to Steven Van Gucht
column17: the suspected deaths are being counted as COVID-19 deaths because not everyone can be tested but said this way of counting saved lives by pointing to the dire situation the care homes were in. After this criticism
column18: the official daily reports started to distinguish the deaths figures between confirmed tested and simply suspected cases.When several countries published excess mortality figures
column19: it appeared that the criticised way of counting caused the reported COVID-19 death toll in Belgium to be closer to the excess mortality figures
column20: compared to other countries. For example
column23: 373 COVID-19 deaths with the excess mortality being estimated around 3
column24: 000. Causing still an underreporting of around 600 deaths. While the neighbouring Netherlands had an estimated excess mortality of 6
column27: 197 reported COVID-19 deaths in that same period. Causing an underreporting of around 3000 deaths. According to professor Yves Van Laethem
column28: Belgium uses the approach recommended by the World Health Organisation and the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
column29: which congratulated Belgium for choosing this approach.

column1: To cope with the increasing influx of patients

column5: the Belgian hospitals started to increase their number of intensive care units around 10 March.Some Belgian hospitals also appealed to the community to help

column7: or Brussels Saint Peter's hospital who called for donations to buy life-saving ventilators.Research to find a vaccine against COVID-19

column10: at the University of Namur (new test method
column11: Benoït Muylkens) and by private companies in collaboration with universities (new 15-minute test method detecting coronavirus antigens
column12: CORIS BioConcept).Studies conducted by Vrije Universiteit Brussel on patients that were being treated for small procedures and who did not have COVID-19 symptoms
column13: showed that approximately 8 % had an infection in the lungs and were infected with the coronavirus
column14: confirming the suspicion that many people are infected with the coronavirus without knowing and as herd immunity would prevent the spread of the coronavirus.Attempts to predict the progress of the coronavirus spread with compartmental models are undertaken at Ghent University (Prof Jan M. Baetens) and Hasselt University (Prof Niel Hens). Professor Barbé at the Free University of Brussels-VUB uses a first order differential equation with two proxy variables. University of Antwerp
column15: with the assistance of KU Leuven and Hasselt University
column16: launched a study to assess the impact of the containment measures and the evolution of the epidemic in Belgium
column17: through a series of online surveys.

column1: In an effort to alleviate the hand sanitiser shortage in Belgium

column3: like the pharmaceutical company Janssen Pharmaceutica
column4: the brewing company AB InBev and the Sugar refinery of Tienen

column1: From 12 March onwards many people started hoarding for the next one and a half-week.The closures and bans ordered by the authorities led to cancellation of many events in the country. For example
column2: Chinese New Year celebrations were cancelled at the University of Leuven.The amount of traffic on Belgian roads dropped sharply after shutdown measures were implemented: traffic dropped by 45% and the structural traffic jams disappeared completely.The Belgian Institute for Space Aeronomy reported that the strong decrease in car and air traffic due to the confinement measures does not necessarily entail as strong a decrease in air pollution. Belgian researchers at the Royal Observatory of Belgium noticed a drop of the background noise on the seismic data that could be the result of transport networks and other human activities being shut down.

column1: The number of confirmed infections is the number of samples tested positive by a reference laboratory. It is estimated that the actual number of cases is much higher than the number of confirmed cases
column2: the tests being limited to specific people and/or to people with severe symptoms. Diagnosed cases are an underestimate of the real number by a factor of between 5 and 10 according to Professor Marc Van Ranst.In the period of 1 to 6 March the number of detected cases grew on average exponentially with a doubling of the number of cases every day. In the period between 7 and 27 March the number of confirmed cases doubled on average every 3.7 days (20.9 % daily increase).

column1: The official reports from the national public health institute of Belgium do not refer to recovered people but only to discharged patients.
The patients are discharged after resolution of symptoms
column2: even though they are not being tested again before leaving the hospital. The number of recovered people who were tested positive but not admitted to hospital remains unknown as there is no follow-up on these cases. The total number of recoveries is therefore underestimated
column3: particularly in a context where there are many undetected positive cases presenting mild symptoms and recovering as well. The situation is similar in France.The first recovered case was on 15 February 2020. As of 5 April
column4: Sciensano reported a total of 3
column5: 986 discharged patients since the 15 March.

column1: In the period between 17 and 21 March the number of deaths due to COVID-19 doubled on average every 1.4 days (64 % daily increase).
As of 3 April 92 % of the fatalities in Belgium were 65 years of age and older
column2: 0.6 % were younger than 45 years and 58 % were men. The youngest fatality overall in Belgium was a 12-year-old girl while the oldest person to die was 104 years.On 25 March 2020
column3: Belgium ranked 6th in the list of EU countries with the highest numbers of casualties
column4: while on 1 April Belgium had the third highest death toll after Italy and Spain. As of 3 April the case fatality rate of the COVID-19 disease is in Belgium similar to the neighbouring countries The Netherlands and France but much higher than in Germany. However
column5: not all countries count the deaths in the same way. Belgium counts deaths occurring both in hospitals and elsewhere
column6: like in care homes. Deaths with clinical symptoms of the coronavirus disease are considered as "suspicious" and are included in the figures of COVID-19 deaths
column7: even if they were not tested.

column6: Brussels and Wallonia.Sciensano started to publish statistics per province starting 18 March. In the period between 17 and 21 March it became clear that the province of Limburg was a hotspot for the coronavirus where the incidence grew much faster compared to the rest of the country: while on 17 March the incidence in Limburg was 1.5 times the average incidence for the country
column7: this had already increased to 1.9 times the average incidence on 21 March.Sciensano started to publish a map with incidence numbers per municipality starting 26 March.The daily Sciensano report of 28 March saw a spectacular rise of the incidence numbers for the province of Liège: from 19 confirmed cases per 100 000 population on 27 March it rose to 77. This was due to underreporting by a lab in the province. On 29 March the province of Liège even became the second worst affected province in Belgium after Limburg.
